title: Italienne (Gaëta)

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of graphite, with stumping, on blue wove paper with blue fibers, perimeter-mounted on cream wove paper wrapped around millboard (touch of red chalk).

description: The young woman who posed for this study probably came from Mola di Gaëta, now known as Formia, a small town in southern Italy. Her heavy dress, with its wide, embroidered sleeves, was typical of the locals. Degas traveled considerably in the vicinity of Rome and Naples in about 1856–59 while, under the sponsorship of the French state, he was a resident at the Villa Medici. Artists slightly senior to Degas had made their name with this kind of imagery, as rural Italian subjects were popular with buyers back in Paris. Although Degas claimed that he was “not mad about this wellknown Italian picturesque,” this drawing shows he was still keen to try the genre.
medium_display: Graphite, with stumping, on blue wove paper with blue fibers, perimeter-mounted on cream wove paper wrapped around millboard (touch of red chalk)
inscriptions: Inscribed recto, upper right, in graphite: "Mola di Gaëta"; center, right of figure, in graphite: "Roma"; lower right, in graphite: "ph 2349";verso, upper left, in graphite: "ph 2349/2"; lower right, in graphite: "41 x 56"
credit_line: Gift of Dorothy Braude Edinburg to the Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection
publication_history:
Daniel Wildenstein, Degas dans les collections françaises (Paris, Galerie de la Gazette des Beaux-Arts 1955), cat. 13, as Italienne.

Villa Medici, Degas e l’Italia, exh. cat. (Rome, 1984-85), p. 255.

Philippe Brame and Theodore Reff, Degas et son oeuvre: A Supplement (New York, 1984), p. 10.

Suzanne Folds McCullagh (ed.), Drawings in Dialogue: Old Master Through Modern, The Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection, exh. cat. (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 2006), p. 104, cat. 69 (ill.).
exhibition_history:
Paris, Jean-Claude et Jacques Bellier, "D’Ingres à nos jours: acquarelles, pastels, et dessins," 1960, cat. 17.

Art Institute of Chicago, "Drawings in Dialogue: Old Master Through Modern, The Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection," June 3–July 30, 2006, p. 104, cat. 69 (ill.).

Art Institute of Chicago, "The Thrill of the Chase: Drawings for the Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection," March 15-June 15, 2014, no cat.
provenance_text: Estate of the artist [stamp (Lugt 658) recto, in red]; sold, Galerie Georges Petit, Paris, July 2–4  1919, lot 68b, to Joseph Durand-Ruel (1862–1928), Paris; by descent to his daughter, Mme. d’Alayer (née Marie-Louise Durand-Ruel, 1897–1991); sold, Sotheby’s, London, June 22,1993, lot 3, to Dorothy Braude Edinburg, Brookline, MA.; given to the Art Institute of Chicago, 2013.
